questions.text: Which of the following diseases cannot be diagnosed by Tzanck smear?
questions.solution:
Hansen's disease is diagnosed by slit skin smear for acid-fast bacilli using the modified Ziehl-Neelsen technique.

Some important findings on Tzanck smear are as follows:

Tzanck Smear findings Disease
Acantholytic cells Pemphigus, Hailey-Hailey disease
Degenerated necrosed keratinocytes Toxic epidermal necrolysis
Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, Bullous impetigo  
Multinucleated giant cells Herpes simplex virus 1 and 2, Herpes zoster
Henderson-Patterson bodies Molluscum contagiosum
Leishman-Donovan bodies Leishmaniasis
Clusters of basaloid cells Basal cell carcinoma

     

Related Pearl: Tzanck Smear in Dermatology

The Tzanck smear, introduced by the Frenchman Tzanck, is a simple to perform, inexpensive bed side cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular and bullous diseases, in particular herpes.

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

Preparation of Tzanck smear:

  • Viral infections and Blistering disorders - fresh vesicle or intact blister is de-roofed and base is scraped 
  • Suspected tumors - any crust should be removed from ulcerated tumors, and non-ulcerated tumors should be incised with a sharp, pointed scalpel and sample is then obtained with either a blunt scalpel or a small curette
  • The smear should preferably be fixed immediately using Formol-Zenker solution since significant artifacts can result from drying.
  • Tzanck smear can be stained by a variety of methods, most commonly by Giemsa stain. Other stains used are hematoxylin and eosin, Wright, methylene blue, Papanicolaou and toluidine blue. 

Results in Tzanck Smear:

A typical Tzanck cell is a large round keratinocyte with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. The basophilic staining is deeper peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells) due to the cytoplasm's tendency to get condensed at the periphery, leading to a perinuclear halo.

Immunobullous Disorders 
Pemphigus Vulgaris Multiple acantholytic cells (Tzanck cells)
Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells with very few inflammatory cells
Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis(TEN) Necrotizing or degenerating basal cells with scattered inflammatory cells and fibroblasts 
Bullous pemphigoid (BP), Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and erosive lichen planus No acantholytic cells ; Many leucocytes
Cutaneous Infections 
Herpes simplex, varicella, herpes zoster Ballooning degeneration and multinucleated giant cells are seen
Molluscum contagiosum Diagnostic intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson-Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30-35 microns)
Vaccinia, orf, milker's nodules and variola Acantholytic squamous keratinocytes , eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion called a "Guarnieri body"
 Leishmaniasis Leishman-Donovan (LD) bodiesgrouped together in a typical "swarm of bees" fashion, within large macrophages (Wright's cells)
Bullous Impetigo Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells with abundant neutrophils and clusters of coccoid bacteria
Genodermatoses 
Hailey-Hailey disease Multiple acantholytic cells; Direct Immunofluorescence Negative
Darier's Disease "Corps ronds" are isolated keratinocytes with a round shape and an acidophilic cytoplasm. The corps grains are seen as small, hyaline, acidophilic ovoid bodies resembling pomegranate seeds.
Cutaneous Tumours 
Squamous Cell Carcinoma Atypical Squamous Cells
Basal Cell Carcinoma Clusters of Basaloid cells

 

Image : Tzanck smear , showing three multinucleated giant cells in center.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man, with a history of alcohol use presented after a fall. He appeared malnourished, confused, and had grossly impaired memory. On neurological examination, he had reduced coordination, an ataxic gait, dysarthria, and tremors. Despite initiating treatment for alcohol withdrawal and detoxification, his symptoms persisted. An MRI of his brain revealed symmetrical demyelination of the corpus callosum. Which of the following statements is true regarding the given condition?

choices.text: Medial thalamic nuclei and mammillary bodies are involved.
It is a complication of acute alcohol intoxication.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Marchiafava Bignami disease (MBD). It is characteristically associated with a 'sandwich' sign on MRI.

MBD is a rare, idiopathic CNS disorder seen as a complication of chronic alcoholism. Early symptoms may include depression, paranoia, psychosis, or dementia. Seizures, hemiparesis, aphasia, and abnormal movements, and ataxia are also seen. If not promptly identified and treated may progress to coma and death.

It is associated with central degeneration of corpus callosum, sparing the dorsal and ventral parts. This characteristic pattern of degeneration presents as the 'sandwich' sign, best visualized on sagittal MRI of the brain. 

Clinically, conditions such as Wernicke’s encephalopathy, delirium tremens, or pontine demyelination may have similar presentations and their features may overlap. Hence neuroimaging plays a significant role in the accurate diagnosis of MB disease.

Ophthalmoplegia and involvement of mamillary bodies and medial thalamic nuclei are associated with Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, not MBD.

The sagittal MRI image given below shows the characteristic 'sandwich' sign in Marchiafava Bignami disease.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds in a patient's urine will not give a positive reaction to​ Benedict's test?
questions.solution:
Benedict’s test is a test for reducing sugars. Sucrose does not give a positive reaction to Benedict's test as it is a non-reducing sugar.

Principle: All monosaccharides and reducing disaccharides contain a free functional aldehyde or ketone group. When heated in the presence of an alkali, they are converted to enediols, which reduce the cupric compounds (Cu2+) present in Benedict's reagent to an insoluble precipitate of red cuprous oxide (Cu2O).

Composition of Benedict’s reagent:

  • Copper sulfate: Provides the source of cupric (Cu2+) ions
  • Sodium citrate: Complexes with cupric (Cu2+) ions to prevent its deterioration to cuprous ions spontaneously
  • Sodium carbonate: Provides an alkaline pH

Substances giving a positive reaction on Benedict’s test:

  • All monosaccharides such as glucose, galactose, fructose, pentoses
  • Reducing disaccharides such as lactose and maltose
  • Glucuronic acid, homogentisic acid, and ascorbic acid

Clinical correlate: Benedict's test is used to detect the presence of glucose in urine.

The color of the precipitate gives a rough idea of the amount of sugar present in urine. Hence, it is a semi-quantitative test.

Colour of the precipitate Amount of reducing sugar
Green 0.5%
Yellow 1%
Orange 1.5%
Red 2%

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the following clinical finding seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows bilateral periorbital ecchymoses, which is called the panda sign, and it is seen in bilateral anterior cranial fossa fracture. It is also known as panda eyes/raccoon eyes.

The pooling of blood surrounding the eyes is most commonly associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa. This finding is typically not present during the initial evaluation and is delayed by 1 to 3 days. If bilateral, this finding is highly predictive of a basilar skull fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is attached to Whitnall’s tubercle?

choices.text: Check ligament of the medial rectus
Check ligament of the lateral rectus

questions.solution:
Check ligament of the lateral rectus is attached to Whitnall’s tubercle.

Lateral orbital tubercle or Whitnall's tubercle is a small elevation on the orbital surface of the zygomatic bone, just within the lateral orbital margin. It is about 11 mm below the fronto-zygomatic suture.

Four structures are attached to it:

  1. Check ligament of the lateral rectus
  2. Lockwood’s ligament (Suspensory ligament of the eyeball)
  3. Lateral palpebral ligament
  4. Lateral horn of the levator aponeurosis

The Whitnall's ligament or the superior transverse ligament of the eye, is attached to the superior tarsal plate and the orbital bone.

questions.text: Which among the following is false about Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis?

choices.text: White nodule on the anterior surface of iris

questions.solution:
Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis is a chronic condition (not acute).

  • Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis consists of chronic, low-grade iritis with posterior subcapsular cataract and secondary glaucoma.
  • It is rare, unilateral in 90% of cases, occurs between the third and fourth decades of life and is associated with a change in color of the iris.
  • Anterior vitreous opacities and occasionally small white nodules may be present on the anterior surface of the iris. Secondary glaucoma has been reported in 15% of patients at presentation. Vision decreases as the cataract progresses.
  • Treatment is directed towards the management of complications of the condition, including cataract, glaucoma and occasionally, visually significant vitreous opacities. The prognosis for eyes with FHI is good, with almost all eyes achieving visual acuity of 20/40 or better.

questions.text: An orthopaedic surgeon uses a posterior approach while operating on a patient with acetabular fracture. What is this approach known as?
questions.solution:
The posterior approach used in acetabular fractures is known as the Kocher-Langenbeck approach.

The surgical approaches used in the management of acetabular fractures include:

  • Kocher-Langenbeck approach is the posterior approach that provides access to the posterior wall, posterior column, and to transverse fractures. It is also used for handling sciatic nerve injuries.
  • The ilioinguinal approach provides access to the entire anterior column, symphysis pubis, ilium, and sacroiliac joint. The Stoppa approach is a modification of the ilioinguinal approach.
  • The iliofemoral approach is a lateral approach that is rarely used nowadays due to the high rate of complication.

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless swelling of the neck. The histology of the tissue is as given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The slide shows the histopathology of Hashimoto thyroiditis, with:

  • Follicular destruction
  • Reduced colloid with increased interstitial connective tissue
  • Small lymphocyte and plasma cell infiltration
  • A well-developed germinal centre may be seen
  • Hurthle (Askanazy) cells that have abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm lining the follicles

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is also known as struma lymphomatosa or lymphocytic thyroiditis. It is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual & progressive thyroid failure.

Clinical features:

  • Most prevalent between 45-65 years of age
  • More common in females
  • Painless enlargement of the thyroid
  • Hashitoxicosis: When the auto-antibodies attack and damage the follicles, there is a sudden release of thyroid hormones from these follicles. This leads to a transient phase of thyrotoxicosis.
  • Hypothyroidism: Since the follicles are damaged and cannot form the hormones anymore, these patients tend to be in a state of hypothyroidism.

Diagnosis:

  • T3 and T4 are low
  • TSH is raised
  • Autoantibodies against:
    • Thyroid receptors
    • Thyroid peroxidase (TPO)
    • Thyroglobulin

These patients are managed with thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

In patients with long-standing goiter, there is a risk of compressive features and the development of thyroid lymphoma. Such cases can be treated with total thyroidectomy. It may also predispose to papillary thyroid carcinoma.

Other options: 

Option A: Histological features of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid include polygonal to spindle-shaped cells in the form of nests, trabeculae or follicles. Small, round anaplastic cells may be found in some cases and amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin polypeptides are present in the stroma.

The given slide below shows medullary carcinoma of thyroid:

Option C: Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder characterized by hyperthyroidism due to circulating autoantibodies. The thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins bind to the TSH receptors, causing overgrowth of the thyroid gland and increased thyroid hormone synthesis. Histologically, there is acinar cell hypertrophy and hyperplasia with the absence of normal colloid in the tall columnar epithelium (normally the epithelium is flat with colloid). Lymphoid infiltrates, consisting predominantly of T cells, along with scattered B cells and mature plasma cells, are present throughout the interstitium. Germinal centers are common.

The given slide below shows Grave's disease:

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in some autoimmune thyroid disorders

Antibody Disorder
TSH receptor-stimulating Immunoglobulins (TSI) Graves disease
Anti TPO & Anti Tg antibodies Chronic lymphocytic(Hashimoto) thyroiditis

TRBAb

(maternal transmission)

 Transient congenital hypothyroidism (maternal autoimmune thyroid disease)
  • Anti TPO – Anti thyroperoxidase antibody
  • Anti Tg – Antithyroglobulin antibody
  • TRBAb – TSH receptor blocking antibodies

questions.text: Saturnine gout is seen in:
questions.solution:
Saturnine gout is seen in chronic lead intoxication or poisoning.

The features of saturnine gout are the same as primary gout but it affects the knee more than the first metatarsophalangeal joint and tophi rarely develop. Lead exposure should be suspected if a patient presents with the triad of:

  • Saturnine gout
  • Hypertension
  • Renal insufficiency (renal failure and interstitial fibrosis)

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: A dead person was brought for autopsy with suspicion of murder. The police suspected that he was hit on the head after which he was thrown in front of a lorry. On examination, there were multiple fractures on his skull. Which rule is used to determine the sequence of fractures in that skull?
questions.solution:
The sequence of bullet injuries is given by Puppe’s rule.

Puppe’s rule: It is possible to determine the sequence of injuries in skull fractures caused by blunt injuries to the head because the second fracture ends at the point where a break in cohesion is already present. The fracture lines created by every other shot extend only up to the fractured lines produced by the previous shot without continuing over them. Even though this rule is true for all blunt injuries to the skull, it is of particular importance in gunshot wounds. 

Other options

Option A: Nysten's rule:

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. The basic sequence of the rigor mortis begins from the head down the body, in that order. It disappears in the same order of appearance.

The order of appearance of rigor mortis:

  1. Involuntary muscles: Heart
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

Option C: Durham's rule: An accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

Option D:  Casper's dictum: The ratio of the rate of putrefaction of a dead body in air, water, and buried in the ground is 1:2:8.

questions.text: Periodic acid Schiff positive macrophages are seen in:
questions.solution:
Periodic acid Schiff (PAS) positive macrophages are seen in Whipple's disease.

Whipple's disease is a chronic infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei, classically presents as chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, intermittent fever, weight loss, arthralgia/arthritis with neurological(cognitive changes progressing to dementia, personality and mood alterations, hypothalamic involvement and supranuclear ophthalmoplegia) and cardiological involvement (endocarditis, congestive heart failure, embolic events, aneurysms).

Investigations- Intestinal biopsy showing PAS-positive diastase resistant inclusions in lamina propria, specific PCR-based diagnosis has higher sensitivity. Urine PCR is an important tool to assess the success of therapy.

Treatment- IV ceftriaxone (2 g q12h) or meropenem (2 g q8h) for 2–4 weeks and then treated with oral doxycycline, or minocycline plus hydroxy- chloroquine for at least 1 year. Trimethoprim/Sulfamethoxazole is used as an oral alternative, but high relapses.  

Related Pearl: Investigations in Malabsorption Syndrome

The following are the general tests for malabsorption:

Disorder Investigation
Fat malabsorption

Quantitative: 24h fecal fat >7g

Qualitative: Sudan III staining

C14 Triolein breath test

Fecal steatocrit
Carbohydrate malabsorption

D-xylose test

Lactose hydrogen breath test
Protein malabsorption C13 egg-white breath test

The following are the specific tests for malabsorption:

Disorder Investigation
Celiac disease

Anti-tissue transglutaminase (anti-tTG)

Anti-endomysial antibodies

Mucosal biopsy showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, lamina propria infiltrates, and normal mucosal thickness.
Whipple's disease Mucosal biopsy showing PAS +ve macrophages in lamina propria
Pancreatic insufficiency

Fecal elastase

Fecal chymotrypsin
Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO)

Due to Enterobacter or Pseudomonas - jejunal aspirate >103 CFU

Due to other organisms - jejunal aspirate >105 CFU

questions.text: All of the following is an example of Cervical Spine Injury except:
questions.solution:
Jack Knife Injury also known as 'seat belt injury' is an injury usually seen in the Dorsolumbar Vertebrae Injury.

Whiplash Injury, Avulsion Injury and Fall from height all lead to C-Spine Injury.

Clay Shoveller's Fracture is an example for Avulsion injury which may occur with severe voluntary contraction of the muscles at the back of the neck resulting in avulsion of spinous process of C7.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has come with complaints of insomnia, memory loss, and orofacial numbness. On examination, the patient has coarse tremors in his hands and lips. History is suggestive of an intake of bluefin tuna on a regular basis. You suspect an intoxication of a particular poison. Which of the following will be an effective treatment?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of encephalopathy and peripheral neuropathy related to chronic mercury poisoning (Minamata disease). There is no effective treatment for patients with toxic chronic exposure to organic mercury, and hence only supportive care is provided

This is most commonly associated with the consumption of mercury-rich fish (such as shark, swordfish, bonito, mackerel, marlin, and bluefin tuna).

Symptoms are generally resistant to treatment with chelators. Dimercaprol (BAL) should not be used, because it increases the mobilization of mercury to the brain. Treatment with oral DMSA is unlikely to reverse the neurologic damage. Hence, there is no effective treatment for Minamata disease.

For patients with toxic exposure to elemental mercury or inorganic mercury, the following are effective:

  • DMSA (succimer)
  • DMPS
  • BAL (dimercaprol)

For severe acute organic mercury poisoning, succimer is used.

questions.text: A woman complains that her 5-year old child has become very indifferent towards her. He attempts to squeeze his genitals and is always stuffing his mouth with food and objects like knives and toys.  Which of these syndromes could her child be suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 5-year boy who mouths non-food items (hyperorality/hyperphagia), constantly squeezes genitals (hypersexuality), indifferent to parents is suggestive of Kluver-Bucy syndrome.

Kluver Bucy syndrome is characterized by hyperorality, hyperphagia, hypersexuality, hypermetamorphosis (constantly shifting attention). It is due to damage to the temporal lobe and amygdala, which leads to an inability to access memory and emotional connections.

Option A: In medial hypothalamic disease, there is an increase in eating behavior, marked by a lack of satiety and resultant obesity.

Option B: Kleine–Levin syndrome, also known as sleeping beauty syndrome, is a rare sleep disorder characterized by persistent episodic hypersomnia, hyperphagia, and hypersexuality with cognitive or mood changes.

Option D: Charcot Willbrand disease leads to loss of visual imagery with occipitotemporal damage.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with acute alcohol intoxication was being tested in the ER. When stimulated by pinching, his pupils dilated with a slow return. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of McEwan's sign.

Pupils are contracted, but stimulating the person (e.g., pinching or slapping) causes them to dilate, with a slow return. This is a characteristic finding of ethanol toxicity, seen at BAC levels >250 mg%.

questions.text: What is the deformity seen in patients with 'main en griffe'?

choices.text: Extension at metacarpophalengeal joint and flexion at interphalengeal joint
Extension at both metacarpophalengeal and interphalengeal joints
Flexion at both metacarpophalengeal and interphalengeal joints
Flexion at metacarphophalengeal joint and extension at interphalengeal joint

questions.solution:
Extension at the metacarpophalangeal joint and flexion at interphalangeal joints due to ulnar nerve injury produces claw hand (main en griffe).

The ulnar nerve supplies medial two lumbricals in the hand. The lumbricals have a combined action on metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint flexion and interphalangeal (IP) joint extension (glass holding posture).

In ulnar nerve injury, since the medial lumbricals are not functional, the forearm muscles are unopposed. MCP joint goes into hyperextension (unopposed activity of extensor digitorum, posterior forearm) and IP joints go into flexion (unopposed activity of flexor digitorum muscles, anterior forearm) and they bring about the claw hand deformity. 

The image given below shows the ulnar claw hand (main en griffe). Note the hyperextension at MCP joints and flexion at IP joints.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presented with a loss of sensation over the hand as marked in the given image. Which of the following statements is true regarding the affected nerve?

choices.text: It innervates medial half of flexor digitorum profundus
Ape thumb deformity can be seen irrespective of site of lesion
Wrist drop can be seen if the lesion is above the elbow

questions.solution:
The nerve supply of the region marked in the image is the median nerve. The ape-thumb deformity is seen in the median nerve lesion irrespective of the site of the lesion, as it is a defect of the end of the nerve. It is caused by non-use atrophy of the muscles of the thenar eminence (except adductor pollicis). 

Median nerve supply:

Branch Muscles/ region
Median nerve

Superficial flexors (pronator teres, flexor carpi radialis, palmaris longus, flexor digitorum superficialis)

Exceptions: flexor carpi ulnaris, medial half of flexor digitorum profundus
Anterior interosseous nerve

2 ½ muscles:

Flexor pollicis longus, pronator quadratus, lateral half of FDP (medial half by ulnar nerve)
Recurrent branch Thenar muscles (except adductor pollicis)
Palmar cutaneous branch Lateral 2/3rd of palm
Palmar digital nerves

Lateral 2 lumbricals

Skin over the lateral 3 ½ digits

The sensory nerve supply to hand by median nerve is given below.

Option A: Adductor pollicis is innervated by the ulnar nerve.

Option B: Median nerve innervates lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus. Ulnar nerve innervates medial half of flexor digitorum profundus.

Option D: Wrist drop is seen in radial nerve palsy.

Note: Thenar muscles include abductor pollicis, adductor pollicis, opponens pollicis, and flexor pollicis brevis. Adductor pollicis is called the graveyard of the ulnar nerve because after supplying all other muscles medially it ends laterally in adductor pollicis.

questions.text: This kind of apraxia is typical of Alzheimer's disease, when an act can be performed in isolation, but a series of acts cannot be executed as a whole in an organised manner. The apraxia is known as:
questions.solution:
Ideational apraxia occurs when the individual components of a sequence of skilled acts can be performed in isolation, but the entire series cannot be organized and executed as a whole.

  • For example, the sequence of opening an envelope, removing the letter, unfolding it, and placing it on the table cannot be performed in order, even though the individual acts can be performed in isolation.
  • A lesion in the left parietal cortex and prefrontal cortex (responsible for sequencing and execution) causes ideational apraxia.
  • This apraxia is a typical finding of diffuse cortical degeneration, such as Alzheimer's disease.

Apraxia:

The skilful use of the hands is called praxis, and deficits in skilled movements are termed apraxias.

The three levels of apraxia are:

Limb-kinetic -

  • Inability to use the contralateral hand even though there is strength.
  • A lesion in the supplementary motor area causes limb-kinetic apraxia.

Ideomotor -

  • Inability to do an act on command, despite preserved comprehension, strength, and spontaneous performance of the same act.
  • Disconnection of the Wernicke's area (language comprehension) from the motor regions causes ideomotor apraxia.

Ideational or conceptual apraxia -

  • Inability to perform a sequence of acts as a whole.
  • A lesion in the left parietal cortex and prefrontal cortex causes ideational apraxia.

Constructional apraxia -

  • Inability of patients to copy accurately drawings or three-dimensional constructions.
  • It is a common disorder after right parietal stroke, often persisting after initial problems such as visuospatial neglect have resolved.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with a known cerebral vascular anomaly and seizures presented to your OPD. She gives a two-week history of objects around her appearing to be larger than they actually were, and that she noticed deformations in objects. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Perceptual distortion of shape, size, color and reciprocal position of objects is known as Alice in Wonderland syndrome (AIWS). It is seen in schizophrenia and migraine. AIWS may be secondary to seizures associated with an arteriovenous malformation.

 

Option A: Kleine-Levin syndrome is characterized by hypersomnia, hyperphagia, and hypersexuality. 

Option B: Kanner syndrome is characterized by the failure to develop an attachment with a parental figure and a preoccupation with inanimate objects.

Option D: Pickwickian syndrome is sleep apnea associated with hypersomnia, in elderly and obese persons.

questions.text: What is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy.

Other examples of rare hereditary neuropathies are Friedreich’s ataxia, familial amyloid polyneuropathy and Tangier disease.

questions.text: A young college student presents with multiple episodes of falls while climbing stairs. He stated he had been feeling clumsy and weak for the past few months. On examination, he was found to have bilateral positive Babinski's sign and atrophy of muscles of lower limbs. Deep tendon reflexes were absent. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with both UMN (positive Babinski sign) and LMN (absent reflexes and wasting of muscles) signs are suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). It is also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, after the famous New York Yankee baseball player who was affected with the disorder.

ALS was first described by Charcot in the 19th century and is also referred to as Charcot's disease.

Option A: Kennedy disease is a gradually progressive neuromuscular disorder characterised by wasting of proximal and bulbar muscles. It is caused by a mutation in the androgen receptor gene.

Option C: Pelizaeus–Merzbacher disease is an inherited leukodystrophy characterized by problems with coordination, motor skills, and learning.

Option D: Charcot-Marie-tooth disease encompasses a group of hereditary sensory and motor neuropathies.

questions.text: A man who mistook his wife for a hat is brought to the psychiatric OPD. The psychiatrist after interviewing him suspects a brain lesion. To localize the lesion and to determine its effects, which of the following tests can he use as a neuropsychological assessment tool?
questions.solution:
Halstead Reitan test is a neuropsychological test and is used to detect and localize brain lesions and determine their effects.

This approach typically includes a large variety of tests that measure most cognitive domains, as well as sensory and motor skills.

Related Pearl: Neuropsychological tests

The neuropsychiatric evaluation combines information from neurological, neuropsychological testing, and mental status examinations.

The following are some common neuropsychological screening tests and test batteries: 

  • Wisconsin card sorting test
  • Wechsler memory scale
  • PGI memory scale
  • Bender Gestalt test or BG test
  • Benton visual retention test or BVRT
  • Luria-Nebraska neuropsychological battery
  • Halstead-Reitan neuropsychological test battery

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Whipple's triad?

choices.text: Symptoms of hypoglycaemia after fasting or exercise
Relief of symptoms on intravenous administration of glucose

questions.solution:
Elevated plasma levels of insulin is not a component of the triad. Whipple's triad is a clinical condition characterised by an insulin-producing tumour of the pancreas called insulinoma. 

The components of the triad are:

  • Symptoms of hypoglycaemia after fasting or exercise.
  • Plasma glucose levels <2.8 mmol/L.
  • Relief of symptoms on intravenous administration of glucose.

Patients with insulinoma eat frequently to avoid hypoglycemic symptoms. Hence, weight loss is not a feature of insulinoma.

questions.text: Shortly after birth through normal vaginal delivery, a neonate develops petechiae and purpura. You suspect bleeding disorder and send samples for further workup. A prolonged bleeding time, normal platelet count, normal aPTT is seen along with large platelets in the peripheral smear. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bernard–Soulier syndrome is the likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario.

The presence of petechiae and purpura at birth, especially after vaginal delivery, along with prolonged bleeding time, normal platelet count, normal aPTT are seen in qualitative platelet defect disorders like Bernard-Soulier syndrome and Glanzmann's thrombasthenia.

The presence of large platelets rules out Glanzmann's thrombasthenia. Evans syndrome is an autoimmune hemolytic disorder with thrombocytopenia. Von Willebrand's disease doesn't usually manifest at birth. 

Bernard–Soulier syndrome is an autosomal recessive functional/qualitative platelet disorder. It is characterized by the deficiency of Gp Ib-IX receptor causing defective platelet adhesion. It is due to genetic mutations in the genes forming the GPIb complex of glycoproteins Ibα, Ibβ, V, and IX.

Laboratory parameters:

  • Normal platelet count (or mild thrombocytopenia)
  • Large platelets (megathrombocytes) with dense granules
  • Bleeding time abnormally prolonged
  • Platelet aggregation tests are normal (with collagen, adenosine diphosphate [ADP], epinephrine)
  • Ristocetin aggregation test is abnormal/no response
  • von Willebrand factor (vWF) levels are normal.

Related Pearl: Platelet disorders

Finding

Bernard–Soulier syndrome

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia

von Willebrand Disease
 Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Autosomal recessive

 Most common (type 1): Autosomal dominant
 Defect

Absence of Gp Ib-IX-V receptor

 Absence of Gp IIb/IIIa receptor

Type 1: Partial quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF)

Type 2: Qualitative defect of VWF

Type 3: Complete quantitative deficiency of VWF 
 Mechanism

Lack of Gp Ib-IX-V prevents platelet adhesion to VWF

 

Platelets cannot aggregate as Gp IIb/IIIa normally binds fibrinogen and forms bridges between platelets 

There are 2 mechanisms:

Platelet adhesion defect - due to absent vWF that normally binds to GPIB-IX and collagen in the subendothelium

Factor VIII deficiency as vWF usually prevents its degradation
Platelet count  Normal platelet count/ mild thrombocytopenia  Normal Normal (except in type 2B- thrombocytopenia)
Platelet morphology Large platelets/ megathrombocytes with dense granules Normal  Normal/ large
Bleeding time

Prolonged

 Prolonged  Prolonged
Platelet aggregation tests (collagen, ADP, thrombin) Normal Abnormal  Normal
Ristocetin aggregation test

Abnormal (platelets does not aggregate)

Does not normalize after addition of normal serum

Normal

(aggregation of platelets)

 Abnormal, Normalizes after addition of normal serum
VWF factor levels Normal Normal  Decreased
PT/PTT Normal Normal  PT normal, aPTT prolonged

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy develops hypoglycemia and muscle weakness with moderate activity. On examination, he had hepatomegaly and growth restriction. Investigations revealed the accumulation of limit dextrins and increased glycogen deposits in the liver. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Cori disease.

Glycogen debrancher deficiency (Glycogen Storage Disease III) is also known as Cori disease, Forbes disease, and limit dextrinosis.

Cori’s disease may be clinically indistinguishable from von Gierke’s disease in infancy and childhood as hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and growth retardation is common. Accumulation of limit dextrins is unique to Cori's disease. Definitive diagnosis is through enzyme assays in the liver, muscle, or both.

Related Pearl: Glycogen Storage Diseases

questions.text: Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for diagnosis of which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis. 

It is based on the principle that the presence of anti-toxoplasma antibodies in the patient's serum inhibits the staining of trophozoites by alkaline methylene blue dye. Toxoplasma trophozoites and complement are added to the patient's serum which is then incubated for an hour at 37°C. After incubation, methylene blue dye is added.

  • If anti-toxoplasma antibodies are present in the serum, these are activated by complement and the parasite membrane is lysed. Thus, the trophozoites are not stained (positive result).
  • If there are no antibodies, trophozoites will take up the stain and appear blue under the microscope (negative result).

The dilution of the test serum at which 50% of the tachyzoites are not stained is reported as the antibody titer of the test serum. The test is highly sensitive and specific. However, it cannot differentiate between recent or past infections as it detects only IgG antibodies.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presented with sudden onset of loss of pain and temperature on the right side of his face and left side of his body. He also has dysphagia and dysarthria. Thrombosis of which vessel is likely to cause the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome or Wallenberg syndrome, which is seen in thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

The lateral part of the medulla is supplied by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery, a branch of the vertebral artery. Injury or thrombosis to this artery results in lateral medullary syndrome leading to: 

Signs and symptoms: Affected structures:
Contralateral loss of pain and temperature on the body Lateral spinothalamic tract
Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature on the face Spinal sensory nucleus of V nerve
Ataxia and intention tremors Spinocerebellar tract
Vertigo, nausea, vomiting, and nystagmus Vestibular nuclei
Dysphagia, dysarthria and hoarseness of voice Nucleus ambiguus
Ipsilateral Horner syndrome Sympathetic fibers

 

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

  • C/L hemiplegia

questions.text: Vikas, a high school student is observed to have an indented 'en coup de sabre' lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
En coup de sabre lesion is seen in juvenile localized scleroderma (morphea).

It appears as an indented, vertical, colourless, line of skin on the forehead. The indentation looks as though the person may have been struck (coup) by a sword (sabre). This lesion involves the scalp and/or face and often extend into the central nervous system, resulting in neurologic sequelae such as seizures and headaches.

questions.text: A child presented with fever and multiple erythematous tender plaques. On microscopic examination, the skin lesions have neutrophilic infiltration in the dermis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Neutrophilic infiltration of the dermis indicates one of the diseases under neutrophilic dermatosis. Sweet's Syndrome presents as an acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis which is characterized by non‐itchy, sometimes tender, erythematous plaques and papules.

The plaques are often oedematous and as the process develops they may become studded with pseudovesicles or pseudopustules (no fluid collection present).

The lesions in Sweet's Syndrome are most commonly distributed on the arms, upper body, head, and neck. An associated fever and peripheral leucocytosis are commonly seen and females are more frequently affected.

Histological findings include a dense dermal neutrophilic infiltrate with edema. Three subgroups are recognized:

  • Classical
  • Malignancy-associated
  • Drug-induced

Option A: Behcet's syndrome is also a neutrophilic dermatosis but presents as recurrent oral and genital aphthous ulcers with an erythematous halo.

Option B: Pyoderma gangrenosum, another neutrophilic dermatosis presents as painful ulcerative erythematous plaques or papules with undermined violaceous borders.

Option C: Kasabach-Merritt's syndrome shows hemangiomas with thrombocytopenia.

The image given below shows Sweet syndrome- pseudovesicles may occur within the inflammatory plaques.

questions.text: A 58-year-old lady presents with pain, swelling, and discoloration in her left thumb for 4 months. On examination, the following clinical sign is noted. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The above image shows melanonychia with the pigmentation of proximal nail fold which is called the Hutchinson's sign. It is seen in subungual melanoma.

In benign nail pigmentation due to drugs (eg. minocycline) or injury (hematoma), the colour stays within the margins of the nail plate and doesn't extend to nail folds.

Option A: Frank's sign - diagonal crease in the earlobes of adults has been associated with an increased risk for atherosclerotic heart disease.

Option B: Fitzpatrick sign (Dimple sign) - squeezing the skin adjacent to a dermatofibroma causes a dimpled appearance on its surface. It is also termed a positive pinch sign or dimple sign.

Option D: Pastia's sign - linear petechial eruption in the skin folds especially on the ante-cubital fossa and axillary fold seen in streptococcal scarlet fever.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of a patient with Tourette's syndrome?

choices.text: Persistence of tics for at least 6 months
Presence of at least one vocal tic

questions.solution:
Tourette's syndrome is diagnosed when there is a persistence of tics for at least 1 year.

According to DSM-5 criteria, a diagnosis of Tourette's disorder depends on:

  • A history of multiple motor tics and the emergence of at least one vocal tic at some point.
  • Tics may wax and wane in frequency but must have persisted for more than a year.
  • The average age of onset of tics is between 4 years and 6 years of age, although the peak age for the severity of tics is between 10 and 12 years.
  • The onset of symptoms must occur before the age of 18 years. No tic-free period of more than three consecutive months in 1 year.

questions.text: Which of the following would you use to screen an asymptomatic sibling of a patient with Wilson's disease?
questions.solution:
Genetic testing for the ATP7B gene is used to screen asymptomatic 1st and 2nd-degree relatives of patients with Wilson's disease. This helps to differentiate the heterozygous from the homozygous individuals. This can be useful in the early initiation of treatment before the onset of symptoms.

Low serum ceruloplasmin, raised 24 hr urinary copper and Kayser-Fleischer rings are diagnostically helpful.

Estimation of hepatic tissue copper is the gold standard for diagnosis. It is measured using neutron activation analysis / atomic absorption spectrometry.

questions.text: What is the most common inherited ataxia?
questions.solution:
Friedreich's ataxia is the most common form of inherited ataxia (autosomal recessive), comprising one-half of all hereditary ataxias.

Friedrich's ataxia has autosomal recessive inheritance and presents before 25 years of age. The median age of death is 35 years. Women have a significantly better prognosis than men.

Friedrich's ataxia presents with clinical features such as dysarthria, progressive staggering gait, frequent falls and titubation. Other neurological symptoms include nystagmus, loss of fast saccadic movements, loss of vibratory and proprioceptive sensation, and ataxia or trunk and limb movements. The lower extremities are more severely involved than the upper ones.

Cardiac involvement occurs in 90% of patients. It presents with cardiomegaly, symmetric hypertrophy, and conduction defects. Musculoskeletal deformities are common and include progressive scoliosis, pes cavus, and pes equinovarus.

questions.text: All  the features about  Meige's syndrome are  true  except _______

choices.text: Affects women older than age 60 years

questions.solution:
Impaired speech is not a feature of Meige's syndrome.

  • Meige's syndrome  is a combination of oromandibular dystonia and blepharospasm that predominantly affects women older than age 60. years.
  • Oromandibular dystonia is a type of focal dystonia.

Focal dystonias (most common forms of dystonia)

  • Blepharospasm
  • Oromandibular dystonia
  • Spasmodic dysphonia
  • Cervical dystonia
  • Limb dystonias

questions.text: A first-standard child was referred for evaluation of suspected autism. According to his parents, he has trouble with social interactions and also has certain abnormal repetitive behaviors. He does not have any language deficits or intellectual disabilities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Pervasive developmental disorder, not otherwise specified

questions.solution:
In Asperger's disorder, there are no significant delays in language or cognitive development.

Features of Asperger's disorder:

  • Impairment in social interaction and development - 
    • Markedly abnormal nonverbal communicative gestures
    • Failure to develop peer relationships at the expected level
  • They do not manifest with mental retardation
  • Restricted interests and patterns of behaviour
  • No significant delay in language

Related Pearl: Autism Spectrum Disorder

 

  Autism Rett syndrome Asperger syndrome Heller syndrome
Onset Before 3 years After 5 months After 3 years After 2 years
Gender predilection Boys Girls Boys Boys
Intellectual disability Present in 30% of the cases Present Absent Present
Language Mostly poor Mostly poor Normal Mostly poor
Remarks ---

Normal head circumference at birth.

Regression of milestones

 ---

Normal head circumference at birth.

Regression of milestones

NOTE: Rett's syndrome has been removed from DSM-5 because it was found to have a clear genetic basis.

 
DSM - 4
DSM - 5
Change in Classification 
Pervasive Developmental disorders
Autistic Spectrum Disorder
Number of Domains 
3 domains
2 domains
Impairment in social interaction and communication 
 

  • Delay or total lack of development of spoken language

  • Stereotyped and repetitive use of language

  • Impairment in the use of multiple nonverbal behaviors

  • Failure to develop peer relationships

  • Lack of social or emotional reciprocity
 
 

  • Deficits in nonverbal communicative behaviors

  • Deficits in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships

  • Deficits in social-emotional reciprocity 
Repetitive and restricted
interests/behaviors 
 
  • Stereotyped and repetitive motor mannerisms

  • Inflexible adherence to specific, nonfunctional routines

  • Persistent preoccupation with parts of an object
 

  • Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements

  • Insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines

  • Highly restricted, fixated interests.

  • Hyper- or hyporeactivity to sensory input

questions.solution:
Cowden syndrome is associated with PTEN mutation.

questions.text: Water’s view is used to best visualize which of the following sinuses?
questions.solution:
Water’s view is used to best visualize the maxillary sinus. Frontal and ethmoidal sinuses can also be visualized. Sphenoid sinus can be seen in Water's view with open mouth.

It is also known as the occipitomental view. The X-ray beam is angled at 37°-45° to the orbitomeatal line. 

The recommended imaging views for different sinuses are as follows:

  • Ethmoidal sinus: Rheese's view
  • Frontal sinus: Caldwell's view
  • Sphenoid sinus: Hirtz view

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with burning pain and numbness in his hands, heat intolerance and decreased visual acuity. Further evaluation reveals skin angiokeratomas and a decreased renal function. Which of the following is the mode of inheritance of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Burning pain and numbness in hands, heat intolerance, decreased visual acuity with skin angiokeratomas and a decreased renal function is suggestive of Fabry’s disease which is inherited as an X-linked recessive disorder.

Fabry’s disease is a lipid storage disorder due to a deficiency of α-galactosidase A, resulting in the accumulation of globotriaosyl-ceramide in tissues. Young boys present with Fabry crises (burning pain in the hands, feet and proximal extremities), angiokeratomas (reddish blue telangiectatic skin lesions between the umbilicus and knees), corneal and lenticular opacities, renal failure and cardiomyopathy.

Note: All sphingolipidoses are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, except Fabry’s disease.

Most of the common metabolic disorders are autosomal recessive disorders, except:

1. Autosomal dominant disorders:

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia

2. X-linked recessive disorders:

  • Hunter syndrome
  • Fabry disease
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome
  • OTC deficiency

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

questions.text: The principle that “ In spinal cords, dorsal roots are sensory and ventral roots are motor” is known as ______
questions.solution:
The principle that in the spinal cord the dorsal roots are sensory and the ventral roots are motor is known as the Bell–Magendie law.

Laws in Sensory Physiology

  • Muller's doctrine of specific nerve energies: When the nerve pathways from a particular sense organ are stimulated, the sensation evoked is that for which the receptor is specialized, no matter how or where along the pathway the activity is initiated.
  • Law of projection: No matter where a particular sensory pathway is stimulated along its course to the cortex, the conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of the receptor.
  • Weber-Fechner Law: Magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the log of the intensity of the stimulus.
  • Labelled line theory: All the sensations from the different parts of the body travel along specified paths. For example, in the posterior column, fibers from the lower parts of the body are placed medially.

questions.text: Naglazyme is used for treating patients with which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Naglazyme is used in the treatment of Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome.

Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome/MPS VI is caused by the deficiency of arylsulfatase B enzyme whose gene locus is on chromosome 5. Preservation of intelligence is the feature of this syndrome. It is characterized by macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, macroglossia, short stature, and contractures. 

Naglazyme is used as an enzyme replacement therapy.

Related Pearl: Enzyme Replacement Therapy for Lysosomal Storage Disorders

questions.text: A G2P1 obese woman was diagnosed with arrest of descent during labour. Identify the following manoeuvre performed for this patient.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia and the manoeuvre shown above is the McRoberts manoeuvre. This is the most effective intervention and should be the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia. 

McRoberts manoeuvre:

  • Flexion and abduction of the maternal hips (positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen).
  • The pelvic rotation which occurs due to the straightening of the sacrum tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder of the baby. 
  • Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this manoeuvre.

If the first line of management fails, proceed with internal rotational manoeuvres such as Rubin's and Wood corkscrew in McRoberts position.

Rubin's manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the easily accessible shoulder towards the anterior aspect of the chest from under the pubic symphysis by 30-45° while staying in the McRoberts' position. 
  • Pressure is applied on the scapular aspect (posteriorly) of the shoulder.

Wood corkscrew manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the posterior shoulder by 180° in a corkscrew fashion to lie beneath the pubic symphysis while staying in McRobert's position.
  • Pressure is applied on the clavicular aspect (anteriorly) of the shoulder.

questions.text: During post-op rounds, you note one of the patients has developed fever and flank pain. The nurses inform you that her abdominal drain outputs have been consistently high. Which of the following procedures has the highest incidence of the complication suspected here?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of ureteric injury. The highest incidence of this complication is seen with Wertheim’s hysterectomy.

Urinary tract injury occurs almost exclusively in major gynecologic surgery that involves surgical dissection in proximity to the ureters or bladder. Vaginal hysterectomy tends to have lower rates of ureteric injuries than open (abdominal, Wertheim) or laparoscopic routes. The highest risk for ureteric injury is associated with the following procedures:

  • Surgical debulking of gynecological cancers
  • Advanced pelvic reconstructive surgery
  • Laparoscopic hysterectomy

Patients with ureteric injuries have a complicated post-operative period. They can present with the following features:

  • Fever
  • Flank pain
  • Abdominal distension
  • Prolonged paralytic ileus - bowel sounds are absent
  • High drain outputs, in case abdominal drains are placed.

CT urogram and retrograde pyelography are the investigations of choice. They reveal urinary extravasation from the ureter. Ureteric injuries are prevented by careful division of tissue planes during pelvic or genitourinary surgeries. The condition is managed by prompt surgical repair by ureteroureterostomy or percutaneous ureterostomy.

questions.text: A patient presented with serous discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. On examination, the location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. According to Goodsall's rule at what position from the dentate line will the internal opening be palpated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of fistula-in-ano with external opening at 8’O clock position which implies that the external opening of the fistula is lying posterior to the midline. According to the Goodsall rule, fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline. Hence, the fistulous tract opens internally at a 6’O clock position.

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin.

Goodsall’s rule:

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to this rule often occur. Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline

questions.text:
Match the following criteria used for the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy:
Ectopic pregnancy Criteria
1) Abdominal A) Spiegelberg
2) Cervical B) Studdiford
3) Cornual C) Rubin
4) Ovarian
questions.solution:
Ectopic pregnancy Criteria
Abdominal Studdiford
Cervical Rubin
Ovarian  Spiegelberg

Spiegelberg’s criteria used for the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy include intact ipsilateral tube, pregnancy occupying ovary connected by the utero-ovarian ligament.

Studdiford’s criteria used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy include the presence of normal bilateral tubes and pregnancy related to the peritoneal surface.

Rubin's criteria used for the diagnosis of cervical pregnancy includes presence of soft, enlarged cervix and closed internal os and partially opened external os.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with pain in the right wrist following a fall on the outstretched hand. On examination, tenderness was noted in the anatomical snuff box. Radiograph of her wrist is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and radiograph showing a large gap between the scaphoid and lunate are suggestive of scapholunate dissociation. 

It is also known as tooth gap sign or Terry Thomas sign, after the English comedian.

questions.text: Most common organ that herniates in Morgagni’s hernia is ______
questions.solution:
The transverse colon is the most common herniating structure in a Morgagni hernia.

Morgagni Hernia:

  • A hernia in the anterior part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments
  • The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.

Morgagni hernia:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus?
questions.solution:
Barrett’s esophagus is a risk factor for adenocarcinoma of the lower end of the esophagus, not for squamous cell carcinoma.

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of esophageal carcinoma.

Risk factors for SCC:

  • Tobacco
  • Alcohol
  • HPV
  • Plummer–Vinson syndrome
  • Achalasia
  • Tylosis
  • Caustic ingestion

Risk factors for adenocarcinoma:

  • Barrett's esophagus
  • GERD
  • Smoking
  • Obesity

questions.text: A 72-year-old female patient presented to the hospital with complaints of difficulty swallowing and generalised weakness for 4 months. Peripheral smear revealed the following and an esophagography was done as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with microcytic hypochromic anemia and characteristic esophagogram is suggestive of Plummer-Vinson syndrome. 

Plummer-Vinson syndrome/Paterson–Kelly syndrome has a triad of:

  • Post-cricoid webs
  • Dysphagia
  • Iron-deficiency anemia

The webs are made up of fibrovascular stroma and esophageal epithelium. Glossitis, angular stomatitis, koilonychia are also associated with this condition.

Laboratory investigations reveal microcytic-hypochromic blood picture and barium esophagography or esophagogastroduodenoscopy(EGD) will help detect post-cricoid webs. 

Treatment includes correcting the iron-deficiency anemia which may improve dysphagia and pain. Esophageal bougies can be used during upper endoscopy to dilate the post-cricoid webs and allow normal swallowing and passage of food.

Complications include the risk of perforation during dilatation and also malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma. 

The image below shows endoscopic appearance of post-cricoid web.

questions.text: A patient is shifted for emergency laparotomy for the management of an intra-abdominal haemorrhage, following a road traffic accident. Intraoperatively, you find an active bleed from the liver. Which of the following techniques will you use to control the bleed?
questions.solution:
The hepatoduodenal ligament can be clamped to decrease active hemorrhage from the liver. This is called Pringle's maneuver.

This maneuver applies pressure on the portal triad which contains bile duct, portal vein and hepatic artery. This helps distinguish hepatic arterial and portal venous bleeding from hepatic vein bleeding. Hepatic venous bleed will persist with the hepatoduodenal ligament clamped. The liver laceration can then be explored and any actively bleeding vessels controlled with suture ligation.

4 P's in the management of liver injuries are: 

  • Push - compression of the edges of the laceration
  • Pringle - applying pressure on the portal triad
  • Plug the defects with silicon tubes
  • Pack - apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding.

questions.text: Which vessel is not involved in the formation of mickey mouse sign that is seen while performing a duplex ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Mickey mouse sign is seen in transverse B mode image of duplex ultrasound formed by:

  • Common Femoral Vein (CFV)
  • Common Femoral Artery (CFA)
  • Greater Saphenous Vein (GSV) at the Saphenofemoral junction (SFJ).

It represents the normal anatomy of the femoral vessels as seen in a duplex ultrasound.
